title: Which is better: Amazon Fire Stick, Apple TV, or Roku? Why? - Quora

response.answer_text: Apple TV Vs. Roku Vs. Amazon Fire Stick Vs. Chromecast: Which Streaming Device Is Right For You? The Best Streaming Devices for the Cord-Cutter on Your List I’ve been a Roku user (multiple models) since 2011. I also own an Amazon Fire Stick, an Apple TV, and a Google Chromecast (v2). As far as which is better, the answer is “it depends”. For example, if you use Apple computers, iPhone, iPad, and purchase content (music, movies, etc) via Apple’s App Store, then an Apple TV is probably best for you. If you purchase content via Amazon, a Fire Stick might be best. Roku is a content-independent vendor (Roku started as the hardware division of Netflix). Personally, I’ve stuck with Roku, using both Roku 3 and Streaming Stick+ (you need one device for each TV set). While Roku isn’t perfect, I’ve found that it’s a great crossover, with apps able to support Amazon Prime, Netflix, Hulu, Google Play, or even Google’s newer live channels YouTube TV (all fee services requiring separate subscriptions). Roku also supports in-home PLEX media servers (but not native KODI, so far as I know). I also don’t think Roku supports streaming content from the Apple Store. All of these internet streaming devices are essentially small computers, and as time goes on, you may need a new version to support a feature you want. Smart TVs have an internet streaming capability built-in, but they’re not hardware upgradeable. That’s why even if you have a Smart TV, you may add a Roku Streaming Stick+ at some point in the future, so that you can upgrade your streaming capabilities. Or you may replace an older 1080p Smart TV with one capable of 4K resolution (twice that of 1080p). As time goes on, you find new features available on Roku. For example, the Roku Remote now supports TV power on/off and volume up/down, so you only need a single remote control. New versions all support voice search via their remotes, and Roku has an excellent smartphone app which can replace the need for a remote, and it also allows “private listening” where sound from Roku channels plays only on your headset (so as to not disturb others in the same room). Followup questions? Add them in the Comments.

I’ve extensively used all three, own both Apple TV and Roku devices, and have set up to many Firesticks to count. That being said, I’d give the clear hardware edge to Apple TV. It’s simply a more power device. It’s much more responsive than the other two, seems to stream more easily, offers an impressive amount of storage, and is flat out better IF you’re already invested into the Apple ecosystem. I think Roku is still the “King of Content” as you can seemingly find just about anything you want on it. Not only does Roku offer hundreds (if not thousands) of free-content channels, but they now have their own Roku Chanel that offers some pretty nifty stuff that’s add-supported and free. Another nod I’d give to the Roku is that they tend to keep their platform more “open” than Apple or Amazon. As of this writing, they don’t have much in the way of “Roku produced content”, but have started to resell HBO and other pay services directly from their channel store. Time will tell what this does to the openness of their platform, but I’ve not noticed much of a change as of yet. I think Amazon Fire Sticks are just “fine”. They don’t really wow me, I’ve had more stuttering and streaming issues with them. They tend to push Amazon Prime solutions pretty heavily. But the nice thing is that they’re cheap and they tend to work pretty easily right out of the box. If you’re already invested in Apple products and iTunes content, and can afford it, I feel the Apple TV is a tremendous device. I think Roku hardware is just solid all around. If you’re on a budget or have a few Alexa devices in your home, a Fire Stick can be a decent solution…but there’s pretty cheap Roku stuff out there to be had!
